restriction: Bottled water allowed. No other food or drink.
address: Cambridge University Library, West Road, Cambridge, CB3 9DR
title: UL - Reading Room
description:
The Main Reading Room of the University Library is very quiet, spacious and constantly staffed. The room has a very high ceiling and is low-lit. There are rows of workspaces across the room, each with overhead table lights. It could be considered one of the more intense study spaces and is where the University Library's Research and Information Services Department is located. Staff are always on hand to answer any questions. We can offer specialist advice on the reference collections and on starting your research.  

P﻿lease note that due to work on the West Room roof, there is currently noise from the building site. Staff can offer ear plugs and there are noise cancelling headphones available for your use.

W﻿e offer Click & Collect services and can refer you to the Scan & Deliver team. for more details and updates on the services that the University Library can offer you. You can find out more information on our Using the Library webpage.

building: Faculty of Architecture and History of Art
address:
1-5 Scroope Terrace
Cambridge
CB2 1PX
title: Faculty of Architecture and History of Art – Ground Floor: Architecture and History of Art Room
description:
The library is located in the Faculty of Architecture and History of Art Building on the ground and basement floor. There is a variety of seating and study areas and the room has plenty of natural light coming from windows overlooking Trumpington Street. Step-free access is available to the ground floor of the library by lift from the central faculty corridor. If you have any accessibility needs, please let the library staff know and we will be happy to help.

Please check information on the [AHA LibGuide](https://libguides.cam.ac.uk/architecture-art) so you can plan your visit.

Step-free access to the ground floor and most of the basement is available by lift from the central faculty corridor. If you have any accessibility needs, please let the library staff know and we will be happy to help. Library staff are happy to fetch any items for library users. Please check information on the [AHA LibGuide](https://libguides.cam.ac.uk/architecture-art) so you can plan your visit.

restriction: The Library is open to students being taught in PDN as well as researchers and staff based in the Department. If you are from outside of the PDN Department and wish to visit the Library, then please contact us in advance to discuss arrangements. The Library is open 24/7 to department members with card access, or in line with the opening hours of the Physiology building (8:45-12:30, 13:30-17:00 Monday-Thursday, 16:00 on Friday) .

title: PDN Library – Bookable study room
description: Bookable, small room with circular table and several chairs. The room has a wall-mounted TV screen for displaying digital content from a laptop via an HDMI connection. Ideal for group work or catching up on the latest conference stream.

restriction: The Library is open to students being taught in PDN as well as researchers and staff based in the Department. description: O﻿pen plan space with wooden workbenches with individual plug points and USB charging. Well-lit with large windows letting in lots of natural light as well as some overhead strip lighting. A sofa and beanbag area is also located in this space as is a larger table for group working. The room is separated into two zones by a number of fixed bookcases.

restriction: The Library is open to students being taught in PDN as well as researchers and staff based in the Department. address: The Library, Department of Physiology, Development and Neuroscience, Downing Street, Cambridge, CB2 3EG
title: PDN Library – Quiet study space
description: Open plan space with several rows of wooden tables with individual plug points and USB charging. Well lit with large windows letting in lots of natural light as well as some overhead strip lighting. A sofa, beanbags and a standing desk are available. Some standing bookshelves can be found in this area, as can the Library Office where you can find the PDN Librarian.

restriction: Open 24/7 for current members of the Department and undergraduate students taking Part II Plant Sciences. Other NST-B students taking Part IB and Part II courses taught by the Department may also be given card access to the Library between the hours of 8am and 9pm after they have attended a Library induction. All other students and non-members of the Department or the University may visit during staffed hours only. Please contact the Library in advance to discuss arrangements.
imagealt: Plant Sciences Library. There are two large circular tables with four chairs surrounding each. imagealt: Plant Sciences Library. There are 6 office chairs at a desk which runs around the edge of a narrow bay. There are bookshelves behind the desks to the left and right. At the end of the bay is a large, ceiling height window with ginkgo leaves visible outside.
address: Downing Site, Downing Street, Cambridge, CB2 3EA
title: Plant Sciences Library – Bays
description: Traditional study desks in the Plant Sciences Library provide space for quiet, individual study. There are three docking stations with a monitor, keyboard and mouse to connect to your own laptop, and a computer for searching and viewing Electronic legal Deposit materials

restriction: The Library is open to members of the Department of Plant Sciences, staff at the Botanic Garden, the Sainsbury Laboratory and those working in the University Herbarium from Monday to Friday, 8:00 – 17:00. Before your first visit to the Library, please get in touch with us so that we can arrange to introduce you to the space and collections, and set up access. All other non-members of the Department may access the Library by appointment, during staffed hours.
imagealt: Cory and Herbarium Libraries. address: 47 Bateman Street, Cambridge, CB2 1LR
title: Cory & Herbarium Libraries
description: Modern library space with horticultural and botanical collections. The space is quiet with large desks for individual work. There are very few plug sockets available and the space is temperature controlled so best to wear an extra layer when visiting.

restriction: Department of Genetics members can access the Library 24/7. Other University members wishing to visit may contact the Librarian to arrange entry during normal staffed hours.

title: Genetics Library
description: The Genetics Library is open to department members only, unless by appointment. The Library is a modern space with plants and plenty of natural light. There are six individual study spaces, as well as a Windows PC, a Mac and an e-legal deposit terminal. The Library also contains a CO2 monitor and an air purifier, and windows can be opened easily. Follow the website link below for more information about access and facilities.

title: Philosophy - Reading Room
description:
We can be tricky to find, so take a look at <https://www.phil.cam.ac.uk/library/finding-us> before your first visit. In our small, but cosy, reading room you'll find large shared desks, four individual study spaces, a height-adjustable desk, bean bags and cushions, and an iDiscover terminal. This area may suit those who prefer working in a calm and quiet space. Visit our website for more information about our services, facilities (including location of toilets, these are also tricky to find!) and opening hours (these can vary, especially during the vacations).

F﻿or updates about the Library please see our [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/lewylibrary/)

restriction: You must be a registered with the library to study at the UL
address: Cambridge University Library, West Road, Cambridge, CB3 9DR
title: UL - North Front Corridor
description: The North Front Corridor is a bright wide space in an open shelving area where readers and staff will often walk by. It's a cooler area with easy access to both the North Front and the North Wing. There are no plug sockets on the tables, though electrical outlets are not far away on the wall opposite. You are also free to work in the enclosure by the Tea Room and Map Room. The enclosure has two computers available for use and is a cosy study space. You can also access the North Courtyard, where food and drink can be taken.

Raised Faculty Building
Sidgwick Avenue
Cambridge
CB3 9DA
title: Philosophy - Computer Area
description:
We can be tricky to find, so take a look at the [Get Directions link](https://www.phil.cam.ac.uk/library/finding-us) before your first visit.

 In this area you'll find one student PC, a screen to plug into your own device, a non-print legal deposit machine, photocopier/scanner/printer and height-adjustable desks.  There is also a small sofa in this area.  Located next to the library reception desk, this area may suit those who prefer working with some background noise. Visit our website for more information about our services, facilities (including location of toilets) and opening hours (this can vary, especially during the vacations).

description:
There are three wide desks across the floor that can seat up to 4 people at once, with computers available at each desk. The space is air conditioned, so it is nice and cool in the summer months. You can access West Four from the Alpha and Beta staircases/lift. You can find periodicals and books related to Asian and Middle Eastern studies there too. 

The University Library also offers: Book a Visit (to consult collections), Click & Collect, Scan & Deliver, Ask a Curator (special collections expertise). Follow the Website link at the bottom of this listing for more details and updates.

The Fourth Floor Landing provides a very quiet space where readers very rarely frequent. You will experience some movement, but compared with the rest of the UL, this is a remarkably quieter space. Warm, spacious and cosy. 

The Library also offers: Book a Visit (to consult collections), Click & Collect, Scan & Deliver, Ask a Curator (special collections expertise).

address:
Downing Street
CAMBRIDGE 
CB2 3DZ
title: Haddon: Main Reading Room
description:
The Haddon Library is located on the Downing Site of the University of Cambridge. It is at the northern end of the site, on the first floor of the building which houses the Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology. Enter on the courtyard side (not the street side) using the door to the right of the museum and go up a flight of stairs. If you would like to use a lift, please read the information on the accessibility page, see the website link at the bottom of this listing. Parking on the Downing Site is difficult, and public transportation is recommended.

T﻿he Main Reading Room at the Haddon Library has 42 study spaces. 

Follow the Website link at the bottom of this listing for more details and updates.

Cambridge

description:
The Reference Library is open to all, and holds materials relating to the Fitzwilliam Museum's collections. A small space, close to the busy museum café but with views out to the garden of Grove Lodge, with lots of natural light.

Everyone is welcome but booked spaces will take precedence over walk-ups. You can book in advance either by emailing the library or using the enquiry form on the website.
restriction: If requesting materials you must book in advance. Walk-ups are permitted if there's space available.

address: Wilberforce Road, Cambridge CB3 0WD
title: Moore Library - Lower Ground Floor
description:
T﻿he lower ground area offers a range of mixed seating. You will find four and two seater study pods, study desks similar to what you would find elewhere in the building and a large space (the Glass room) with a high concentration of seating which is usually a quiet working area.

T﻿here are also two bookable study rooms. 

O﻿verall this space is a quiet study area.

address: Downing Street, Cambridge, CB2 3EJ
title: Zoology Library - Newton Room
description: Small study area with one large desk and four seats and two smaller desks with two seats each.

address: Cambridge University Library, West Road, Cambridge, CB3 9DR
title: UL - South Reading Room
description:
The South Reading Room is a very comfortable and cosy space with plenty of soft seating. This is a very quiet space with access to bookable acoustic booths and coffee tables. The toilets are just around the corner and you are within equal distance to both the Main Reading Room and the Readers Services Desk; both of which are constantly staffed. The help desk is also just outside, and printers and scanners are not far away, the nearest being in the South Reading Room Corridor.

The Library also offers: Book a Visit (to consult collections), Click & Collect, Scan & Deliver, Ask a Curator (special collections expertise). Follow the Website link at the bottom of this listing for more details and updates. https://www.lib.cam.ac.uk/using-library/zero-contact-services

restriction: Booking required to study at the UL
address: Cambridge University Library, West Road, Cambridge, CB3 9DR
title: UL - North Reading Room
description:
The North Reading Room is a spacious room with multiple computers and plenty of desk space for laptops. There are printers and scanners nearby in the Reading Room South corridor, the help desk is right next door on the 1st floor landing, and you are in equal distance to both the Main Reading Room and the Readers Services Desk. 

The Library also offers: Book a Visit (to consult collections), Click & Collect, Scan & Deliver, Ask a Curator (special collections expertise). Follow the Website link at the bottom of this listing for more details and updates. https://www.lib.cam.ac.uk/using-library/zero-contact-services

address: Cambridge University Library, West Road, Cambridge, CB3 9DR
title: UL - South Front 5
description:
A well-lit space in a very quiet part of the University Library. Plug sockets are available and there is a good view out of the window. Tables are smaller, air is cooler and there are rarely many people around.

The Library also offers: Book a Visit (to consult collections), Click & Collect, Scan & Deliver, Ask a Curator (special collections expertise). Follow the Website link at the bottom of this listing for more details and updates. https://www.lib.cam.ac.uk/using-library/zero-contact-services

address: Cambridge University Library, West Road, Cambridge, CB3 9DR
title: UL - Rare Books Room
description:
The Rare Books Reading Room is a quiet and comfortable space, warmer than some others and open to everyone for the consultation of the UL’s collections of items printed before 1950 and other printed material that is rare or needs careful handling. 

Opening Times for the Rare Books Reading Room are below, however, the Rare Books Department relocates to the Manuscripts Department on the third floor from 1700 to 1850 Monday to Thursday, 1645 to 1850 on Friday and 0900 to 1630 on Saturdays.

address: Cambridge University Library, West Road, Cambridge, CB3 9DR
title: UL - Manuscripts Reading Room
description: Reading room open to everyone for the consultation of the UL’s archive and manuscript collections. Material is fetched on request. It’s not necessary to make an appointment but it is helpful to contact the manuscripts team in advance to let them know when you want to come and what you want to see. Details of most archival collections are available on ArchiveSearch. More details: Visiting the Manuscripts Reading Room. The Library also offers: Click & Collect, Scan & Deliver, Ask a Curator (special collections expertise). Follow the Website link at the bottom of this listing for more details and updates.

restriction: For information on how to access the UL, please see: http://www.lib.cam.ac.uk/plan-your-visit/admissions/who-can-use
address: Cambridge University Library, West Road, Cambridge, CB3 9DR
title: UL - Anderson Music Room
description: The Anderson Room is open to everyone for the consultation of the UL’s collections of printed music and books about music printed after 1900. Earlier materials will be fetched to Rare Books or Manuscripts as appropriate.  The Library also offers: Click & Collect, Scan & Deliver, Ask a Curator (music collections expertise).

imagealt: UL - Aoi East Asian Reading Room
address: Cambridge University Library, West Road, Cambridge, CB3 9DR
title: UL - Aoi East Asian Reading Room
description: The East Asian Reading Room is a warm and welcoming study space, very quiet and provides a perfect environment for those wishing to study in a relaxed, warm and silent place. The Library also offers: Book a Visit (to consult collections), Click & Collect, Scan & Deliver, Ask a Curator (special collections expertise). Follow the Website link at the bottom of this listing for more details and updates.

address: Cambridge University Library, West Road, Cambridge, CB3 9DR
title: UL - Reading Room South Corridor
description:
The Reading Room South Corridor is a quiet corridor located next to the south courtyard. The supplementary catalogue is located here and staff can be found in the Reading Room right next door.
There is a networked printer available for printing, scanning and copying.
The Library also offers Click & Collect, Scan & Deliver and Virtual Reading Room services.
For more details on these services please go to [Zero Contact Services]() (https://www.lib.cam.ac.uk/using-library/zero-contact-services)

address: Cambridge University Library, West Road, Cambridge, CB3 9DR
title: UL - North Wing Corridor
description:
The North Wing Corridor is a cooler space near the open stacks and has several large desks available. Printers and scanners are nearby, with the closest by the Rare Books Reading Room, and you are very close to the tearoom, toilets and the north courtyard. 

The Library also offers: Book a Visit (to consult collections), Click & Collect, Scan & Deliver, Ask a Curator (special collections expertise). Follow the Website link at the bottom of this listing for more details and updates. https://www.lib.cam.ac.uk/using-library/zero-contact-services

restriction: Library is open Saturdays, out of term, except during the Summer vacation.
address: Wilberforce Road, Cambridge CB3 0WD
title: Moore Library - Ground Floor
description:
T﻿he Betty and Gordon Moore Library (known as the Moore) is a STEMM library with a strong collections emphasis towards Mathematics and the Physical Sciences. The Moore also has good collections across other STEMM collections. We also have excellent sections in literature, research and study skills and wellbeing. 

T﻿he ground floor area is the principle staff work area and where you will find the service desk. There are also large round tables that can be used for group study, University managed desktop PCs, self-service issue/return kiosk, E-legal deposit PC, an acoustic booth (which can be booked through the website) and the public printer/scanner.

address: Cambridge University Library, West Road, Cambridge, CB3 9DR
title: UL - South Wing Corridor
description: The Library also offers: Book a Visit (to consult collections), Click & Collect, Scan & Deliver, Ask a Curator (special collections expertise). Follow the Website link at the bottom of this listing for more details and updates.

address: Cambridge University Library, West Road, Cambridge, CB3 9DR
title: UL - South Front Corridor
description: The South Front Corridor is a bright wide space in an open shelving area where readers and staff will often walk by. It's a cooler area with easy access to both South Front and South Wing. There are no plug sockets on the tables, though electrical outlets are not far away.

address: Cambridge University Library, West Road, Cambridge, CB3 9DR
title: UL - Map Room
description:
The Map Department is home to the majority of Cambridge University Library's cartographic resources, from early printed and manuscript maps through to modern resources including Ordnance Survey digital map data.
The Room has specially designed tables and benches for viewing the collections largest items. It also houses the card catalogue and Ordnance Survey Map Data PC. 
Staff are always on hand to help access the collection for both first time and experienced users. Readers may use laptops and other connected devices in the Map Room at any desk. Plug sockets are provided in all the desks and benches.
It is possible to make arrangements, on application to a member of the staff in the Map Room at least 20 minutes prior to the time of closing, for the transfer of most material to the Munby Rare Books Room for use there after the Map Room closes.
Please note that it may not be possible to consult some of the largest items in the collection outside of the Map Room due to their size.

O﻿PENING TIMES
Monday to Thursday : 9am to 12:45pm and 2pm to 5:10pm
Friday : 9am to 12:45pm and 2pm to 4:50pm

restriction: For information on how to access the UL, please see: http://www.lib.cam.ac.uk/plan-your-visit/admissions/who-can-use
address: Cambridge University Library, West Road, Cambridge, CB3 9DR
title: UL - Tea Room
description:
The UL Tea Room is a great place to meet up with friends and take a break from work. The atmosphere is chatty and social. The Tea Room is also suitable for taking phone calls/meetings. You can treat yourself to barista coffee, and a daily-changing variety of sandwiches, paninis, snacks and cakes. Serving hours are 9am to 3pm. You are also welcome to eat your own food in the Tea Room.

Users without their own water bottle can ask for a paper cup from the Reader Services Desk in the Entrance Hall, in order to use the cooler.

restriction: Access is through a controlled reception area. The reception is staffed 9am-12:30pm & 1:30pm-5pm on weekdays, department members with card access can visit outside of these hours.

imagealt: UL - South Wing 3 Study Hub - Commonwealth Room
address: West Road, Cambridge, CB3 9DR
title: UL - South Wing 3 Study Hub - Commonwealth Room
description: This reading room is light and spacious, providing a quiet space to study with few distractions. It houses a good number of public computers and has a copier/printer. There are large desks and some smaller reading nooks available.

imagealt: UL - South Wing 3 Study Hub - Group Study Room
address:
Cambridge University Library,
West Road,
Cambridge,
CB3 9DR
title: UL - South Wing 3 Study Hub - Group Study Room
description:
The Group Study Room is a new bookable space for groups to meet and discuss their studies. It is located on the third floor, signposted from the nearby Beta staircase.

Online bookings can be made for up to 8 people for a session lasting 90 minutes. Only one person per group needs to make the booking. 

Each booking runs for 90 minutes during standard opening hours Monday-Saturday, with a 30 minute break between booked sessions.

At present, only one group can book to use the space for each available session. There are two tables available, each with five chairs.

We have actively risk assessed all spaces and space usage in accordance with University guidance on Covid-19, and have further safety measures in place including high quality mechanical ventilation in most areas of the building and a CO2 monitoring program.

We have deliberately factored in 30 minute breaks between each booking, to give a clear break between occupation - you are allowed to open the windows in the room but please remember to close them before you vacate at the end of your booking.

Our Student Experience Team will be in touch after your booking with a short survey to ask you about your experience booking and using this room.

restriction: Library is open Saturdays, out of term, except during the Summer vacation.
address: Wilberforce Road, Cambridge CB3 0WD
title: Moore Library - 2nd Floor
description:
T﻿he 2nd floor is at the top of the building and whilst, generally, a quiet space to work - can benoisy for some due to the large windows that automatically open, which are in the roof section of the building. This allows the wind to blow through which some people don't like - though others might find it the kind of background noise that aids concentration. 

S﻿eating is arranged around the outer edge of the floor and offers nice views across the site and beyond.

address: Cambridge University Library, West Road, Cambridge, CB3 9DR
title: UL - South Wing 3 Study Hub
description: The South Wing 3 Study Hub is a suite of rooms that allow you to find the study space that suits you. Comprised of; the group study room, individual accessibility bookable study room, individual bookable study room for online zoom calls/supervisions etc, Commonwealth Reading Room (no booking required for this space), and bookable desks and lockers for PhD students in the Commonwealth Room, we hope you can find a space that is right for you.

imagealt: UL - South Wing 3 Study Hub - Individual Accessibility Bookable Study Room
address: Cambridge University Library, West Road, Cambridge, CB3 9DR
title: UL - South Wing 3 Study Hub - Individual Accessibility Bookable Study Room
description: This is a bookable room, within the Group Study Room, equipped with height adjustable furniture.

imagealt: UL - South Wing 3 Study Hub - Individual Bookable Study Room
address: Cambridge University Library, West Road, Cambridge, CB3 9DR
title: UL - South Wing 3 Study Hub - Individual Bookable Study Room
description: This is a bookable room, within the Group Study Room, perfect for online zoom calls, supervisions or lectures, as well as general study.

address:
West Hub, 
JJ Thomson Avenue
Cambridge, CB3 0US
title: West Hub
description:
West Hub is the University of Cambridge’s first publicly open co-working hub, providing flexible spaces in which to learn, socialise and collaborate.

We are open to everyone and feature a range of work and social spaces across three floors. We support group study / discussion or more individual, focused work. There is also a range of catering options and a shop with Post Office counter.

address: 184 Hills Road, Cambridge, CB2 8PQ
title: Education Library - Lower Ground Floor
description:
The Lower Ground Floor of the Library has some of the prettiest views in the Faculty. Study benches run the length of the windows overlooking the Faculty garden, where you can watch the squirrels, birds and sometimes ducks! 

The Library Living Room (also on the Lower Ground Floor) gives you an opportunity to rest, refresh and recharge.  Be creative with colouring books, ponder our puzzles or charge up your phone!   You will also find laptop stands (there are a few scattered around the Library too), desk lamps for extra light or blankets if the weather turns a bit chilly – the Library is Not Just a Roomful of Books!  

***For current Education Library opening hours, please email the Library team to check before your visit, particularly during vacations as times will change: [library@educ.cam.ac.uk](mailto:library@educ.cam.ac.uk)***

Follow the Website link at the bottom of this listing for more details and updates. You can also find the library on [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/edfaclib/).

address: 184 Hills Road, Cambridge, CB2 8PQ
title: Education Library - Lily Pad 1
description:
T﻿he Education faculty library has over a hundred study spaces. The upper levels of the Library (called Lily Pads) provide some cosy study areas, with some overlooking the front of the building.  You’ll even come across the odd bean bag, too! If you find it more comfortable to stand, then there are 3 standing desks available.

***For current Education Library opening hours, please email the Library team to check before your visit, particularly during vacations as times will change: [library@educ.cam.ac.uk](mailto:library@educ.cam.ac.uk)***

Follow the Website link at the bottom of this listing for more details and updates. You can also find the library on [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/edfaclib/).

description:
The SPRI library is open to all students, researchers and staff of the University of Cambridge, the wider polar research community and anybody wishing to know more about the polar regions. Follow the [Website link](https://www.spri.cam.ac.uk/library) for more details and updates.

T﻿he library is open 0900-1700 Monday to Friday but closes for lunch, between 1300-1400, each day.
